newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU to step into Spanish digital TV fight.
newsitem.headline: EU to step into Spanish digital TV fight.

text.p: The European Commission will challenge on Thursday Spanish legislation on decoders to be used for digital television, an issue which has pitted the Spanish government and the opposition Socialist party and their supporting media groups against each other for months.
EU officials said the Commission will start proceedings against Spain for violating several EU treaty provisions and related legislation which ban obstacles to trade in the bloc's single market.
France's Canal Plus has complained to the Commission about the Spanish legislation on decoders, which effectively bans the pay-television channel from using its technology in Spain.
Canal Plus has teamed up with Spanish media group Prisa, which controls influential left-wing newspasper El Pais, to launch digital television in Spain.
Canal Plus's decoders are already used in other EU countries.

Telecommunications operator Telefonica de Espana and state-television RTVE are planning to launch a rival digital package prompting allegations that the government is giving them time to get the project ready.
CanalSatellite, the rival platform, started operations earlier this year.

EU officials said the Spanish legislation violates articles 30 and 59 of the Treaty of Rome as well as directive 83/189 which requires national governments to inform others before taking any technical measures which might create an obstacle to trade.
